newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: RTRS-Australian bonds knocked back again.
newsitem.headline: RTRS-Australian bonds knocked back again.

text.p: Australian bonds were beaten down for the second day in a row as a combination of hedge fund selling, stop-loss orders and profit-taking continued to correct the recent massive rally, traders said.

The September 10-year bond futures contract dived to 91.770 at one stage in the wake of today's A$700 million Treasury bond tender having touched 92.210 just under a week ago in the midst of a post-budget buying frenzy.
"We're hearing from the futures floor that offshore hedge funds have been fairly aggressive again, and obviously the tender didn't help," one trader said.

A weakening U.S. bond market has also dampened the post-budget after glow which took the 10-year bond yield down to its lowest in nearly 2-1/2 years at 7.80 percent, but it still remains well above the 9.0 percent-plus level seen in mid-June.

U.S. bonds slid on Monday as the fear of a tightening in monetary policy after a string of stronger than expected data continued to grip the market, as did forthcoming fresh supply in the shape of two- and five-year note auctions this week.
The key 30-year long bond yield hit 7.0 percent for the first time in four week's, but eased back to 6.97 percent in Tokyo trading amid Japanese bargain hunting.

The local market is also correcting the sharp tightening in yield spreads to other dollar bloc bonds which had taken the 10-year margin to the U.S. down to 120 basis points on Monday. Canada continued to strongly outperform Australia and the U.S., benefitting from its current bullish fundamentals.
The 10-year bond contract ended testing resistance at 91.830 after filling a chart gap down to 91.785 left in early August. Support is seen at the pyschological 91.750.
